This is a composite index of other data. 10:30 AM: Dallas Fed Survey of Manufacturing Activity for October. ----- Tuesday, October 26th ----- 9:00 AM ET: S&P/Case-Shiller House Price Index for August.¬† The consensus is for the Composite 20 index to be up 20.1% year-over-year. This graph shows the year-over-year change in the nominal seasonally adjusted National Index, Composite 10 and C‚Ä¶

entry.title: A policy triangle for Big Techs in finance
entry.summary: Big Techs‚Äô expansion into financial services can bring competition, efficiency, and inclusion, particularly in emerging market and developing economics. But it also gives rise to issues concerning a level playing field with banks, operational risk, too-big-to-fail issues, as well as challenges for antitrust rules and consumer protection. This column presents a policy triangle that highlights the trade-offs between three objectives: financial stability, competition, and data privacy. Handling these challenges requires more coordination on rules and standards, both between domestic authorities and across international borders.

author.name: Erik Feyen, Jon Frost, Leonardo Gambacorta, Harish Natarajan, Matthew Saal

entry.title: 30 Year Mortgage Rates "Highest Since April" at 3.27%
entry.summary:
From Matthew Graham at Mortgage News Daily: Highest Rates Since April, But There's a Catch Over the past 30 days, interest rates have risen sharply. This is true for both mortgage rates and bond market benchmarks like 10yr Treasury yields. ... Translation: at the beginning of the month, traders only saw a small chance of the first rate hike happening in September and no chance for June. Fast forward 3 weeks and September is seen as 100% likely and June is up to about a 60% chance. [30 year fixed 3.27%] emphasis added Click on graph for larger image. This is a graph from Mortgage News Daily (MND) showing 30 year fixed rates from three sources (MND, MBA, Freddie Mac) since 2010.¬†¬†
Go to MND and you can adjust the graph for different time periods.
30 year mortgage rates are moving up, but still historically very low.

entry.title: October 22nd COVID-19: Still Over 70,000 New Cases per Day
entry.summary:
Some important comments from Harvard Professor Subramanian on a recent paper he wrote (that is being misinterpreted): "This paper supports vaccination as an important strategy for reducing infection and transmission, along with hand-washing, mask-wearing, and physical distancing.‚Äù ... ‚ÄúOther research has clearly and definitively established that the vaccines significantly reduce the risk of hospitalization and mortality.‚Äù
Vaccinations are critical, but it is not enough.¬† To get the case count down, we need to do more as Subramanian suggests.
The CDC is the source for all data.
According to the CDC, on Vaccinations.¬† Total doses administered: 411,963,025, as of a week ago 406,570,875, or 0.77 million doses per day.
COVID Metrics
¬†TodayWeek AgoGoal Percent fully Vaccinated57.3%‚Ä¶

entry.title: The Coming Deceleration in House Price Growth
entry.summary:
Today, in the Newsletter: The Coming Deceleration in House Price Growth Excerpt: [This graph] - as of the NAR release yesterday - shows that Case-Shiller followed the median prices up, and that median prices are now falling. ...
This suggests that Case-Shiller will start to show some deceleration in the September or October reports (to be released in late November and December). emphasis added Please subscribe!

entry.title: How public policy affects private schools
entry.summary: Funding changes to NYC public schools led to significant declines in demand for private schools, highlighting the tradeoffs policymakers must consider when passing educational reforms, according to a paper in the American Economic Review.

entry.title: Black Knight: "Forbearance Declines Hit Mid-Month Lull"
entry.summary:
Note: Both Black Knight and the MBA (Mortgage Bankers Association) are putting out weekly estimates of mortgages in forbearance. This data is as of October 19th. From Andy Walden at Black Knight: Forbearance Declines Hit Mid-Month Lull After two weeks of sizable drops in the number of active forbearance plans (as hundreds of thousands of homeowners reached the end of their allowable terms), we saw much more modest improvement this week ‚Äì the same mid-month lull in removal activity that we‚Äôve been reporting on for many months now. According to our McDash Flash daily forbearance tracking dataset, the number of active forbearance plans fell by just 7,300 (-0.6%) this week, with declines of 10,500 among FHA/VA loans and 2,800 among GSE mortgages being partially offset by a 6,000 rise in plan volumes among portfolio and PLS mortgages. That‚Äôs substantially less than last week‚Äôs 143,000 (10%) drop. As of October 19, 1.24 million mortgage holders remain in COVID-19 related forbearance plans, representing 2.3% of all active mortgages, including 1.3% of GSE, 3.9% of FHA/VA and 3% of portfolio held and privately securitized loans. Click on graph for larger image.
Still, on a monthly basis, improvement remains strong, with forbearances declining by 356,000 (-22.3%) over the past 30 days, and the past few weeks have seen the fastest monthly rates of improvement since the start of the pandemic. Some 432,000 homeowners left forbearance in the first 19 days of October, making it the largest single month in terms of exit volumes since October of last year. And with more than 280,000 plans still up for review through the end of October, significant opportunity remains for additional declines through the first few weeks of November. emphasis added

entry.title: Windows Terminal Preview 1.12 Release
entry.summary: Windows Terminal Preview 1.12 is here and it‚Äôs HUGE! This release adds the new features below to Windows Terminal Preview 1.12 and adds the features from this previous blog post to Windows Terminal 1.11. Windows Terminal 1.11 will also be receiving the Defaults page in the settings UI along with the default terminal functionality. The post Windows Terminal Preview 1.12 Release appeared first on Windows Command Line.

entry.title: Informational barriers to hiring
entry.summary: South Africa has one of the highest jobless rates in the world. Giving small business owners there access to better information about labor laws may help boost the country‚Äôs employment, according to a paper in the American Economic Journal: Applied Economics.

entry.title: The rise of advertising giants in the attention economy
entry.summary: Consolidation among advertising intermediaries has recently eroded Google‚Äôs revenues from sponsored search ads, according to a paper in the American Economic Review. The findings may offers lessons for antitrust regulators.

ÎÅùÏù¥ ÏöîÏõêÌï¥ Î≥¥Ïù¥Îäî Ìå¨Îç∞ÎØπ ÏÉÅÌô©ÏóêÏÑú Ïù¥ ÏÉÅÌô©ÏùÑ Î∞îÍøÄ Ïàò ÏóÜÎã§Í≥† Ïù∏ÏãùÌïú ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§ÏùÄ ÏûêÏã†Ïùò ‚ÄòÌÉúÎèÑ‚ÄôÎ•º Î∞îÍæ∏Í≥† ÏûàÎã§. 2022ÎÖÑ ÎåÄÏ§ë ÏÜåÎπÑÏûêÎì§ÏùÄ ÎßâÏó∞Ìïú Î∂àÏïàÍ∞êÏùÄ Ï§ÑÏù¥Í≥†, ÏïûÏúºÎ°ú Ïñ¥Îñ§ Î≥ÄÌôîÍ∞Ä ÏûàÏùÑÏßÄ Í∂ÅÍ∏àÌï¥ÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú, ÌòÑÏû¨Ïùò ÎßåÏ°±ÏùÑ Îä¶Ï∂îÍ≥†, ÎØ∏ÎûòÏóê Ìà¨ÏûêÌïòÎ†§Í≥† ÌïúÎã§. ÏΩîÎ°úÎÇò19Í∞Ä ÎÅùÎÇ† ÎÇ†ÏùÑ ÎßâÏó∞Ìûà Í∏∞ÎåÄÌïòÎ©∞ ÏúÑÏãúÎ¶¨Ïä§Ìä∏Î•º Ï†ÅÎäî ÎåÄÏã†, Ïß†ÌÖåÌÅ¨Î°ú Ï†àÏïΩÌïòÍ≥† Îã§ÏñëÌïú Î∞©ÏãùÏúºÎ°ú ÎØ∏Îûò Í∞ÄÏπòÏóê Ìà¨ÏûêÌïúÎã§. Î∂àÌôïÏã§Ìïú ÎØ∏ÎûòÎ•º Ï§ÄÎπÑÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ ‚ÄòÌòÑÏû¨Ïùò ÎßåÏ°±ÏùÑ ÏßÄÏó∞(ÈÅ≤Âª∂)‚ÄôÏãúÌÇ§Í≥† ÏûàÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§.
Ïù¥ÏôÄ ÎèôÏãúÏóê Ï£ºÎ≥Ä ÌôòÍ≤ΩÍ≥º ÏùºÏÉÅ, ÏÇ¨ÌöåÏôÄ Ï†ïÏ±Ö Ïù¥ÏäàÏóêÍπåÏßÄ Í¥ëÎ≤îÏúÑÌïòÍ≤å Í∞úÏûÖÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú ‚ÄòÍ∞úÏù∏Ïùò ÌÜµÏ†úÎ†•‚ÄôÏùÑ ÌôïÎåÄÌïòÎ†§ ÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§. ÎåÄÏ§ëÏùÄ ÌååÌé∏ÌôîÎêòÏñ¥ ÏûàÏúºÎ©¥ÏÑúÎèÑ, Í∞ïÎ†•Ìïú ÏòÅÌñ•Î†•ÏùÑ ÏõêÌïòÎäî ‚ÄòÏäàÌçº Í∞úÏù∏‚ÄôÏù¥ ÎêòÎ†§Í≥† ÌïòÎäî ÎìØ Î≥¥Ïù∏Îã§. ÌïòÏßÄÎßå ‚ÄòÎãµÎãµÌïú‚Äô ÏÉÅÌô©ÏùÄ Î≥ÄÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÎäîÎã§(2021ÎÖÑ ÏûêÏ£º Í≤ΩÌóòÌïòÎäî Í∞êÏ†ï 1ÏàúÏúÑ‚ÄìÎãµÎãµÌïòÎã§). Í∞úÏù∏ÏùÄ Ï†êÏ†ê Îçî Í≥†Î¶ΩÎêòÏñ¥ Í∞ÄÍ≥†, ÏÜåÎπÑ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Growth by proximity
entry.summary: Enrico Moretti says inventors are more productive when surrounded by other top talent in their field. We spoke with him about his latest paper on agglomeration economies and why they'll remain important in a post-pandemic world of more remote work.

entry.title: A preview of WSL in the Microsoft Store is now available!
entry.summary: The Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) preview is now available in the Microsoft Store as a store application for Windows 11 machines! Installing WSL through the store will allow you to get the latest WSL updates and features faster, and without needing to modify your Windows version. The post A preview of WSL in the Microsoft Store is now available! appeared first on Windows Command Line.

entry.title: Pollution feeds aggression
entry.summary: Air pollution is known to have negative impacts on physical health. Now there is evidence that it also increases aggressive behavior, according to a paper in the American Economic Journal: Applied Economics.

entry.title: Barriers to expanding coverage
entry.summary: There are many impediments to universal healthcare in the developing world. But governments themselves and their bureaucracies may be a key barrier, according to a paper in the American Economic Review.

entry.title: How Does Incarceration Affect Reoffending? Estimating the Dose-Response Function
entry.summary: Journal of Political Economy, Ahead of Print.

entry.title: Expanding broadband access
entry.summary: A lot of people take fast, reliable internet for granted. But limited access to home broadband may be reducing employment and earnings among poorer Americans, according to a paper in the American Economic Journal: Economic Policy.

entry.title: Windows Package Manager 1.1
entry.summary: I‚Äôm excited to share some great news. We‚Äôre releasing Windows Package Manager 1.1. We‚Äôve squashed some annoying bugs and added some highly anticipated features. The Windows Package Manager is being released to Windows 10 (build 1809 and newer) and Windows 11 as an automatic update via the Microsoft Store. The post Windows Package Manager 1.1 appeared first on Windows Command Line.

entry.title: Celebrity politics
entry.summary: Ronald Reagan‚Äôs tenure as the host of G.E. Theater in the '50s and '60s won him electoral support during his political campaigns, evidence of how entertainment media can shape voter decisions, according to a paper in the American Economic Journal: Applied Economics.
